ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I was able to learn the basic language skills: writing, reading, listening, and speaking in the Korean language. This course also enabled me to connect and learn more about Korean culture and traditions.
The basic conversational skill in Korean language.

I learned very good foundational Korean, including the basics of hangul and how to read, write, and speak very basic Korean. I also learned a lot about Korean culture and activities through presentations, lessons, and skits.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of this course are that there are many opportunities to interact with others and learn more about the Korean culture.
I generally enjoyed the class and I think I have learned a lot from it.

This course is very good at fostering an environment ample for learning and collaboration. There is a big sense of community with fellow peers as a result of Professor Back's policy of switching seats each day in order to practice Korean with other students. This allowed us all to get to know one another and to be comfortable when working in groups of 3 or more for skit presentations. One weakness would be how scattered the lesson becomes sometimes. There are a lot of tangents on vocabulary and grammar not included in the formal lesson and difficulty in understanding whether the material was important or not. Furthermore, although the final group project was fun, there was too little time to create a script, record and edit a video, and present it in class. Not everyone has the skills to manipulate video editing software so the bulk of the project falls on one student. Perhaps it would be better to allocate more time between the creation of the video script, editing and comments from the professor, and the actual execution of the video and the due date.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. I think the professor is really helpful and the workload is reasonable.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It is a great introductory language class, and Professor Back is really great at teaching the language. The environment of the classroom is fun and lively and the language itself is interesting to learn.
